intro: Mucizonia lagascae, commonly known as the Galápagos morning glory, is a flowering plant native to the Galápagos Islands. It is a member of the Convolvulaceae family, characterized by its climbing habit and showy, trumpet-shaped flowers. The plant produces vibrant blue or violet blooms that open in the early morning and close by midday. Its leaves are heart-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its vines can grow up to several meters in length. Mucizonia lagascae plays an important ecological role in its native habitat, providing nectar for pollinators and serving as a food source for local fauna.
